channel.title: Why does
channel.description:
the amount of memory rs uses increase everytime you move you mouse? idk if its just me but i hit the ` key to open the dev console and typed "displayfps" so i was at the login screen and notices the memory usage slowly increasing just sitting there doing nothing. i move my mouse around and i notice it increases the memory dramatically. moving my mouse in a circular motion for like 10 seconds adds like 5mb to the memory usage. idk whe they do a garbage collect but it gets pretty high b4 they do on the login screen. i assume it does it more often when u are actually playing(i havent tested anything more then what i am currently posting). so i got it up to 50-60 mb then i opened up the java console from the tray bar, and hit g. it brought the memory back down to 20mb b/c it if u dont know that does a garbage collect.
well i found it a little interesting, and was wondering how much jagex could do to make RS use only as much computer resources it needs(i assume they do better on that when u are actually playing)?

item.title: Why does
item.dc:creator: @xryz xryz
item.description:
@xryz wrote:

[quote=“T4_, post:4, topic:408252”][quote author=xryz link=topic=509534.msg3697403#msg3697403 date=1312523413]

The client does records keyboard/mouse movements.

ok. how often does i record it, every couple ms? its for bot detection right? seems like a waste of resources to me but maybe i dont fully understand the benefits.
[/quote]
Macro detection most likely, how else would they be able to detect bots that use continuous mouse paths?[/quote]

is it just on the welcome screen where it doesnt do anything with the mouse recording? i havent looked into the client code much, but if a bot uses the exact mouse path everytime im sure it will have more flaws jagex could catch other than the mouse path. i assume that when u play the recordings are streamed to jagex. recording mouse clicks seems like all u would need(determine the amount of time it took to get from point a to point b, compare that to control data being an average movement speed and the speed at which is impossible for a human to move).

Andrew Ferguson:

These days it’s not used so much for macro detection as a timer for when your character logs out. It starts counting the log-out timer after your mouse stop’s moving for 60 seconds.

if thats how jagex does that it seems very inefficient and resource wasteful. the checks could be spread out to a second all the way to minute intervals, comparing the values save upon the last mouse move(starts/resets the count)/key press event(resets the time out count). idk if im not seeing this from the correct viewpoint or not. just my idea on that.

Read full topic

item.title: Why does
item.dc:creator: @Andrew_Ferguson The317Guy
item.description:
@Andrew_Ferguson wrote:

These days it’s not used so much for macro detection as a timer for when your character logs out. It starts counting the log-out timer after your mouse stop’s moving for 60 seconds.

The client does records keyboard/mouse movements.
[/quote]

ok. how often does i record it, every couple ms? its for bot detection right? seems like a waste of resources to me but maybe i dont fully understand the benefits.[/quote]
Macro detection most likely, how else would they be able to detect bots that use continuous mouse paths?
